response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and to establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_251] [CHUNK_252] This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations. [CHUNK_256] The measure has been amended to delete the establishment of the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund and change the effective dates to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_260] [CHUNK_261]",
  "appropriations": "The appropriations in the bill have been changed to unspecified amounts. [CHUNK_259] Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance, should it deliberate on this measure, to consider an appropriation amount of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative. [CHUNK_262, NUMBER_24] The committee also requests consideration of $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) to be deposited into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund, which includes $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for projects and supportive services and $189,750 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Housing Finance Specialist I. [CHUNK_262, NUMBER_25] [CHUNK_263, NUMBER_26] [CHUNK_263, NUMBER_27]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The measure was amended by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts. [CHUNK_259] The fiscal projections are now based on amounts the Committee on Human Services & Homelessness has requested the Committee on Finance to consider. [CHUNK_262] These requested amounts are based on previous legislative efforts, such as the ohana zones pilot program which initially appropriated $30,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), and prior funding for the kauhale initiative which was set at $25,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_203, NUMBER_28] [CHUNK_208, NUMBER_32]",
  "agency_impact": "This measure appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative, as the language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund was deleted. [CHUNK_260] [CHUNK_261] The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation is tasked with administering the Supportive Housing Special Fund and establishing one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Housing Finance Specialist I position. [CHUNK_264] The Department of Budget and Finance offered comments that it does not support the creation of any special fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.3, HRS, and questioned if the proposed funds would be self-sustaining. [CHUNK_21] [CHUNK_24]",
  "economic_impact": "Testimony indicates that housing through Kauhale costs around $30,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) per person per year, while incarceration costs $112,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) for each resident per year. [CHUNK_114, NUMBER_8] [CHUNK_114, NUMBER_9] A study by Partners in Care revealed that the recidivism rate for individuals who received housing support was just 12.8% versus 50% without housing support. [CHUNK_103] Additionally, the Return to Home program has potentially saved Hawaii taxpayers $11.2 million (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt), based on an average cost of $82,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) per person per year not in stable housing. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_4] [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_5]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure was amended to delete language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund. [CHUNK_260] Language that attempted to prevent the proper lapse of a general fund appropriation at the end of the fiscal biennium was also deleted. [CHUNK_259] The bill continues to establish a Supportive Housing Special Fund by amending Chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to facilitate the development of supportive housing units for special needs populations. [CHUNK_224] [CHUNK_227]",
  "revenue_sources": "The measure appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_217] [CHUNK_237] The Supportive Housing Special Fund may also include sums from private contributions, proceeds from repayment of loans, interest, fees, other returns, and moneys from other sources. [CHUNK_230] The previously proposed Kauhale Initiative Special Fund and its associated revenue mechanisms have been removed from the measure. [CHUNK_260]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The Committee on Finance is requested to consider appropriations for the biennium beginning in fiscal year 2025-2026. [CHUNK_262] The request includes $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) per year for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) per year for the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_262, NUMBER_24] [CHUNK_262, NUMBER_25] While the bill text has unspecified appropriation amounts, the committee's request details the intended funding levels. [CHUNK_259] [CHUNK_262] Of the special fund amount, $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) is for housing projects and services, and $189,750 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) is for one temporary 1.0 FTE staff position. [CHUNK_263, NUMBER_26] [CHUNK_263, NUMBER_27] The provision that would have prevented the general fund appropriation from lapsing has been deleted. [CHUNK_259] The Department of Budget and Finance noted that any general funds appropriated should lapse no later than June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_21] The effective dates of the bill have been changed to June 29, 3000, and July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_261] No appropriations are provided beyond fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_217] [CHUNK_238] [CHUNK_246] Continued funding for these initiatives would require future legislative appropriations. [CHUNK_256]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation may establish, revise, charge, and collect a reasonable service fee in connection with its financing, services, and approvals related to the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_235] These fees are to be deposited into the supportive housing special fund, creating a potential revenue source. [CHUNK_235] The provision for the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund, which could have included program revenues, has been deleted from the bill. [CHUNK_260]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "Funds from the Supportive Housing Special Fund may be used to make loans to finance the development, pre-development, construction, acquisition, preservation, or substantial rehabilitation of supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_228] Appropriations for the Kauhale Initiative will cover expenses related to the development and operation of kauhale. [CHUNK_218] This continues prior efforts, such as the ohana zones pilot program which initially received $30,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_203, NUMBER_28]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The creation of the Supportive Housing Special Fund implies an ongoing commitment to addressing housing needs for vulnerable populations beyond the initial biennium. [CHUNK_227] The long-term sustainability of this fund will depend on future legislative appropriations and any revenues generated through fees, loan repayments, or contributions. [CHUNK_230] The Kauhale Initiative will be reliant on recurring general fund appropriations for continued operations after the current biennium, as its dedicated special fund was removed from the bill. [CHUNK_260]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This measure was amended to delete language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund; the previous version of the bill included two new special funds. [CHUNK_260] The specific appropriation amounts in the bill have been changed to unspecified amounts, though the committee report requests the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_259] [CHUNK_262, NUMBER_24] [CHUNK_262, NUMBER_25] The provision that attempted to prevent the proper lapse of the general fund appropriation for the kauhale initiative was deleted. [CHUNK_259] Lastly, the effective dates of the bill were changed to June 29, 3000, and July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_261]"
}

in both FY 26 and FY 27 to the Office of the Governor (GOV) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and provides that the appropriations may be transferred to designated departments or agencies for expenditure and shall not lapse at the end of FB 2025-27; establishes the Supportive

individuals and families with special needs; appropriates $12,000,000 in general funds in both FY 26 and FY 27 for deposit into the SHSF and appropriates $12,000,000 in special fund ceiling for the SHSF in both FY 26 and FY 27; and establishes the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund to be administered

Regarding the indeterminate lapse date for the $50,000,000 general fund appropriation to the GOV, B&F notes that pursuant to Article VII, Section 11, of the Constitution of the State of Hawai‘i, no general fund appropriation shall be made for a period exceeding three years. period exceeding three years. Accordingly, any general funds appropriated in FY 26 or FY 27 should lapse no later than June 30, 2028. Furthermore, as a matter of general policy, B&F does not support the creation of any special fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.3, HRS.

HAWAI῾I STATE COUNCIL ON DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES PRINCESS VICTORIA KAMĀMALU BUILDING 1010 RICHARDS STREET, Room 122 HONOLULU, HAWAI῾I 96813 TELEPHONE: (808) 586-8100 FAX: (808) 586-7543 January 28, 2025 The Honorable Representative Lisa Marten, Chair House Committee on Human Services and Homelessness The Thirty-Third Legislature State Capitol State of Hawai῾i Honolulu, Hawai῾i

The Thirty-Third Legislature State Capitol State of Hawai῾i Honolulu, Hawai῾i 96813 Dear Representative Marten and Committee Members SUBJECT: HB431 Relating to Housing The Hawai‘i State Council on Developmental Disabilities (DD Council) STRONGLY SUPPORTS HB431, which appropriates funds for the Kauhale Initiative. Establishes and appropriates funds into and out of the

Initiative. Establishes and appropriates funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. Establishes the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund. This bill represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawai‘i’s most vulnerable populations, including individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD). Hawai‘i’s I/DD population often faces

intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD). Hawai‘i’s I/DD population often faces significant barriers to accessing safe, stable, and affordable housing. Individuals with I/DD are more likely to experience unemployment, limited income, and social isolation, making it exceedingly difficult to secure independent housing. HB431 provides a pathway to addressing these systemic challenges

housing. HB431 provides a pathway to addressing these systemic challenges by ensuring that housing is affordable and integrated with services necessary for residents to thrive. Supportive services funded under this bill, such as case management, life skills training, and assistance with daily living activities, are vital for individuals with I/DD

with daily living activities, are vital for individuals with I/DD to live independently and participate fully in their communities. The promotion of mixed-income rental housing developments, as outlined in HB431, fosters inclusive environments where individuals with I/DD can live alongside diverse populations. This approach reduces stigma and encourages greater community

diverse populations. This approach reduces stigma and encourages greater community understanding and acceptance of individuals with disabilities. support of HB431 Sincerely, Daintry Bartoldus Executive Administrator mmmm. E X E C U T I V E C H A M B E R S K E K E ʻ E N A O K E K I A ʻ Ā I N A JOSH GREEN, M.D. JOHN MIZUNO

ʻ Ā I N A JOSH GREEN, M.D. JOHN MIZUNO GOVERNOR DIRECTOR KE KIAʻĀINA STATEWIDE OFFICE ON HOMELESSNESS & HOUSING SOLUTIONS Testimony of John M. Mizuno Governor’s Coordinator on Homelessness Before the HOUSE COMMITTEE ON HUMAN SERVICES & HOMELESSNESS Tuesday, January 28, 2025 9:00 a.m. Conference Room 329, State Capitol

January 28, 2025 9:00 a.m. Conference Room 329, State Capitol In consideration of House Bill No. 431 RELATING TO HOUSING Aloha Chair Marten, Vice Chair Olds, and Committee Members, My name is John Mizuno. I am the Governor’s Coordinator on Homelessness and the Director of the Statewide Office on Homelessness

Homelessness and the Director of the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions (SOHHS). First, on behalf of my office and Governor Green, I want to thank the House of Representatives and the Majority Caucus for introducing HB431. I am writing in strong support of House Bill 431, which will

writing in strong support of House Bill 431, which will provide funds for the continued implementation of Governor Green’s Kauhale Initiative. This bill also establishes a Kauhale Initiative special fund to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in our efforts to implement the Kauhale Initiative. In addition,

in our efforts to implement the Kauhale Initiative. In addition, HB 431 will establish and appropriate funds into and out of the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some of the

of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some of the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services. HB431 HD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 1 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate

The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui

with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered,

on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session

county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable

public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session

pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to

$5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically

developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units

was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment,

unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of

for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among

targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding

a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. this Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative; (2) Create the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some or all the units are targeted to

in which some or all the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services; and (3) Appropriate funds to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative. legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. This bill represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawai‘i’s most vulnerable populations, including individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD). Hawai‘i’s I/DD population often faces

intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD). Hawai‘i’s I/DD population often faces significant barriers to accessing safe, stable, and affordable housing. Individuals with I/DD are more likely to experience unemployment, limited income, and social isolation, making it exceedingly difficult to secure independent housing. HB431 provides a pathway to addressing these systemic challenges

housing. HB431 provides a pathway to addressing these systemic challenges by ensuring that housing is affordable and integrated with services necessary for residents to thrive. with daily living activities, are vital for individuals with I/DD to live independently and participate fully in their communities. The promotion of mixed-income rental housing developments, as outlined in HB431, fosters inclusive environments where individuals with I/DD can live alongside diverse populations. This approach reduces stigma and encourages greater community

diverse populations. This approach reduces stigma and encourages greater community understanding and acceptance of individuals with disabilities. Human Services & Homelessness January 28, 20025 Page 3 While the issue of homelessness remains, Hawaii has made significant strides. In 2024, SOHHS set new priorities, including the ambitious goal of halving unsheltered homelessness during Governor Green's Administration’s first term (by November 2026). This would mean transitioning approximately 2,200 people

(by November 2026). This would mean transitioning approximately 2,200 people from the streets or remote areas to a home. Several of SOHHS’s priorities focus on expanding the deeply affordable housing inventory for houseless individuals, including kauhale or communal housing. We are making progress, and with the Legislature’s support, we can

are making progress, and with the Legislature’s support, we can continue to move forward, seeking to become the first State in the union to cut chronic homelessness in half. This progress should give us all hope for a brighter future. The Kauhale initiative is not just another housing project. It

The Kauhale initiative is not just another housing project. It is a unique and innovative approach that strives to demonstrate new, cost-effective models of housing and healing. It is built on the foundation of community and responsibility among residents. Kauhale includes many housing types and is sometimes envisioned as tiny

includes many housing types and is sometimes envisioned as tiny homes with shared bathrooms, dining, and cooking facilities. However, they could also be created in repurposed hotels, offices, buildings, dormitories, or apartment buildings. If deep affordability extends from communal responsibility (kuleana) and ownership is built into the design and program

(kuleana) and ownership is built into the design and program plan, any space could be adapted as a kauhale. This is what makes Hawaii and our kauhale initiative different and unique. In 2024, SOHHS established seventeen Kauhale projects, and we recently added the Kulia I Ka Nuu Kauhale in Waianae

recently added the Kulia I Ka Nuu Kauhale in Waianae in 2025, bringing the total to 18. Our goal is to build at least thirty Kauhale by November 2026, with at least three on each neighbor island. This ambitious plan is not just a government initiative but a collaborative effort

is not just a government initiative but a collaborative effort that involves the Governor, the counties, private businesses, faith-based organizations, nonprofit organizations, service providers, and the community. HB431 HD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 1 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate

The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui

with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered,

on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session

county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable

public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session

pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to

$5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically

developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units

was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment,

unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of

for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. targeting extremely low-income households. a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. this Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative; (2) Create the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some or all the units are targeted to

in which some or all the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services; and (3) Appropriate funds to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative.
